Content-Type: text/plain;

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Colin,

Thanks for the very interesting read. I am currently using kmedoid =
clustering for some work I am doing, and your writeup of your approach so f=
ar was very informative.

I personally chose k-medoid clustering because I =
wanted to be able to have clustering based on a "similarity matrix". For th=
e work I am doing I don't think I can create an artificial centroid like k-=
means does, because I have no mechanism for calculating the similarity betw=
een the artificial centroid and any of the actual chromosomes I am attempti=
ng to cluster. My similarity is based on behaviour, not on chromosome simil=
arity, so I can't have an artifiical centroid - there is no way for me to m=
easure it's behaviour.

An alternative to kmedoid which also looks interest=
ing is spectral clustering. It makes use of the spectrum of the similarity =
matrix to perform dimensionality reduction. I haven't got too far into it y=
et, however it definately seems interesting.

Cheers,

Aidan

  ----- Origi=
nal Message ----- 
  From: Colin Green 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent:=
 Sunday, September 13, 2009 3:00 AM
  Subject: [neat] Overview of speciatio=
n by k-means clustering


    My motivation for implementing k-means cluste=
ring and some issues
  encountered along the way are documented here:

  ht=
tp://sites.google.com/site/sharpneat/speciation

  It turns out that origin=
al NEAT's inter-genome distance calculation is
  very similar to Manhattan =
distance and so I implemented it by
  generalising Manhattan distance to in=
corporate something akin to the
  NEAT compatibility coefficients. However,=
 I still don't have the
  correct equation for calculating a centroid when =
using Manhattan
  distance. My initial attempt at the maths suggests there =
is a single
  analytical expression and I strongly suspect that the arithme=
tic
  average is a good approximation for now anyway.

  Colin
